1.q_string: There is no change in the volume of a wire due to change in its length on stretching. The Poisson’s ratio of the material of the wire is:
The increase in the length of a wire on stretching is \(0.025\%\). If its Poisson's ratio is \(0.4\), then the percentage decrease in the diameter is:

Two wires of the same length and made of the same material, but having radii in the ratio \(1 : 2\) are stretched by two unequal forces to produce equal elongation. What is the ratio of the two forces?

An increase in pressure required to decreases the \(200\) litres volume of a liquid by \(0.004 \%\) in the container is:

(Bulk modulus of the liquid \(=2100 MPa\) )
A spinner swings a cricket ball due to:
Which of the following is the most elastic?
A wire can be broken by applying a load of \(200~N\). The force required to break another wire of the same length and the same material, but double in diameter, is:

A wire of length \(2\) m is made from \(10\) cm\(^{3}\) of copper. A force \(F\) is applied so that its length increases by \(2\) nm. Another wire of length \(8\) m is made from the same volume of copper. If the force \(F\) is applied to it, its length will increase by:
When a long spring is stretched by \(2\) cm, its potential energy is \(U\). If the spring is stretched by \(10\) cm, its potential energy will be:

A wire of length \(L\) and area of cross-section \(A\) is stretched through a distance of \(x\) metres by applying a force \(F\) along the length. The work done in this process is (\(Y\) is Young's modulus of the material)
Which of the following is not a unit of Young's modulus?

A wire elongates by \(l\) mm when a load '\(W\)' is hanged from it. If the wire goes over a pulley and two weights of '\(W\)' each are hung at the two ends, the elongation of the wire will be (in mm):

A body of mass \(10~kg\) is attached to a wire \(0.3~m\) long. Its breaking stress is \(4.8 \times 10^{7} N /~m ^{2}\). The area of cross section of the wire is \(10^{-6}~m ^{2}\). The maximum angular velocity with which it can be rotated in a horizontal circle without breaking is:

A steel wire of cross-sectional area \(3 \times 10^{-6}~m ^{2}\) can with stand a maximum strain of \(10^{-3}\) Young's modulus of steel is \(2 \times 10^{11}\left( N / m ^{2}\right)\). The maximum mass the wire can hold is ..... \(\left[g=10\left( m / s ^{2}\right)\right]\)

A student performs an experiment to determine the Young's modulus of a wire, exactly \(2~m\) long, by Searle's method. In a particular reading, the student measures the extension in the length of the wire to be \(0.8~mm\) with an uncertainty of \(0.05~mm\) at a load of exactly \(1.0~kg\). The student also measures the diameter of the wire to be \(0.4~mm\) with an uncertainty of \(0.01~mm\). Take \(g =9.8~ms ^{-2}\) (exact). The Young's modulus obtained from the reading is:
